section.name: Hippo ECM Architecture

subsection.name: Overview
subsection.p: The Hippo Repository has three main layers as illustrated with the diagram above. The yellow layer represents the persistence layer, consisting of a database and a lucene index. This is where all the actual data is stored. The blue layer represents the main engine. The blue layer is where all the logic is done. The green layer is the API layer. All applications that are connected to the Hippo Repository use these APIs to communicate with the Hippo Repository.

section.subsection: The JCR 1.0 API is a fully compliant with JSR 170.

subsection.name: Hippo Facet Engine
subsection.p: Hippo Facet Engine works out of the box, and does not need any configuration to start with. Browsing through faceted navigation gives you a virtual structured view with counting on your (unstructured) physical data. The facet engine works through intelligent indexing in Apache Lucene, and is extremely fast, as if you are browsing through a (fast cached) File System.
The Facet Engine can be configured if fast faceted browsing on some indirect value, like the week number of a date, is needed. See Search Index at the bottom.

section.subsection: The database is used to store the actual content. A wide range of databases is supported, such as: MySQL, Oracle, MS SQL, Derby and PostgreSQL.

subsection.name: Lucene
subsection.p: Content and meta data is indexed through implementation of Apache Lucene 2.2.0 search engine library. It is a scalable, high-performance indexing, accurate and efficient search algorithm cross-platform Open Source application, with a strong prospering community.

Some of the possible searches through Lucene that are enabled are listed below
and/not/or queries
faceted searching
phrase queries
wildcard queries
proximity queries
fuzzy queries
range queries
synonym searches
similarity searches
spellchecker / did you mean
